awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Extreme climate perturbations by meteorite impacts and volcanism on terrestrial planets
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth is still the only planet known to harbor life at the present. Mars, our best studied neighbor in the Solar System, is known to have been habitable intermittently in the past. The work proposed here will shed light on the processes that have shaped the two planets. Both Earth and Mars have undergone volcanism and giant impacts. There is evidence that Mars had surface liquid water at a time when it was very cold but impacts and volcanic events (both of which could affect the temperature) were extremely common. The project will work to explain the effects of these two processes simultaneously, rather than separately. The investigator will use computer models to create a wide range of possible outcomes for varying levels of volcanic and impact activity. The results will be useful to terrestrial exoplanet studies as well as to the Solar System. The investigator will build and expand upon an outreach program to children 5-7 years old that he has begun in the Cambridge, MA, area. He works with teachers to present age-appropriate activities in astronomy and planetary science, and he will involve his students to give them experience interacting with the public. 

The proposed program will address three key problems in impact/volcano climate forcing in the Solar System. The role of impacts on Mars in early episodes of fluvial erosion 3-4 Ga will be considered. On Earth, the effect of the eruptions that may have triggered an important Snowball event will be studied. Finally, he will use the insight gained from these case studies to make general predictions about extreme perturbations in climate for any terrestrial planet, including exoplanets. He will use state-of-the-art modeling tools, starting with 1D circulation models and working up to 3D models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand how extreme events such as meteorite impacts and massive volcanic eruptions affect the atmospheres, climates and habitability of terrestrial planets over time. This is an important problem because most models of planetary climate focus on steady-state conditions, but external influences have a huge effect on planetary climate evolution. Our research was focused on tackling this problem for Earth and Mars, where we have the best observational data, but our results also had important implications for exoplanets.

Our research revealed that extreme events drove some of the most important episodes in the history of both planets. For Mars, we found that early evidence for liquid water could be explained by episodic warming due to greenhouse gas release from volcanoes and meteorite impacts. We also found that this warming of the planet is tied to chemical change, both through mineral interactions at the surface and the escape of hydrogen to space at the top of the atmosphere. Our results have important implications for ongoing and future Mars missions, including Mars Sample Return.

For Earth, we have found that Snowball events - perhaps the most dramatic climate change in our planet's history - can be driven by the emplacement of massive lava fields called 'large igneous provinces'. Through a combination of simple and complex modeling, we have been able to come up with an explanation for why Earth was sensitive to these events in the Neoproterozoic era (1000 to 538.8 million years ago), but not at other times in Earth history.

The success of any research project can be measured not just by the number of problems solved, but also by the number of new questions generated. In this respect, our project has also been a major success. Our work has generated many important new questions in Earth science and planetary science that we are now pursuing ourselves and with collaborators. Ultimately, by bringing new insight to how Earth and Mars have evolved over time, our project has increased our understanding of the conditions that allow planets to support life in general.
